entries.title: Google is delaying a portion of employee bonus checks
entries.description: Instead of paying full bonuses in January, Google is deferring 20% of bonus checks by at least two months, according to documents viewed by CNBC.

entries.title: Texas Instruments replaces CEO Rich Templeton with current operating chief Haviv Ilan
entries.description: The chipmaker tried a similar move in 2018 but the operating chief selected to become CEO ended up resigning for violating conduct rules.

entries.title: Japan has the No. 1 most powerful passport in the world for 2023—see where the U.S. lands on the list
entries.description: The 2023 Henley Passport Index deemed the Japanese passport the world's most powerful for the fifth consecutive year.

entries.title: Netflix founder Reed Hastings is giving up his CEO role
entries.description: Hastings co-founded Netflix in 1997. Ted Sarandos was promoted to co-CEO alongside Hastings in July 2020.

entries.title: Early Facebook investor says Zuckerberg isn't cutting costs fast enough
entries.description: Jim Breyer believes Meta isn't cutting costs fast enough and that the metaverse is years away.

entries.title: Fed Governor Lael Brainard sees high rates ahead even with progress on inflation
entries.description: Brainard insisted that the Fed won't waiver in its commitment to taming prices that have come down some, but remain near four-decade highs.

entries.title: The whole West is threatened if an aggressor isn't challenged, Dutch PM says
entries.description: The whole of Europe could be at risk if Russia isn't challenged, according to the Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte.

entries.title: Alec Baldwin to be charged with involuntary manslaughter in 'Rust' movie set shooting
entries.description: Alec Baldwin will be criminally charged in the fatal on-set shooting of "Rust" cinematographer Halyna Hutchins.

entries.title: Yellen says Treasury is taking extraordinary measures to avoid default as U.S. hits debt limit
entries.description: Yellen previously said she believes the U.S. government can keep paying its bills until at least early June by deploying extraordinary measures.

entries.title: UK Labour leader Starmer slams PM's Davos no-show, touts new 'inverse OPEC' alliance
entries.description: U.K. opposition Labour Party leader Keir Starmer on Thursday hit out at Prime Minister Rishi Sunak for opting not to attend the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

entries.title: Irish premier hopeful of post-Brexit trade talk breakthrough — but ‘we’re not there yet’
entries.description: Irish premier Leo Varadkar on Thursday said there has yet to be a breakthrough over Northern Ireland's post-Brexit trade rules.

entries.title: France contends with widespread strikes as unions take to streets against pension reform
entries.description: Unions have made common front in widespread demonstrations across all of France.

entries.title: Former Indian central bank governor says a soft landing will be 'very hard' for the Fed
entries.description: The U.S. Federal Reserve will find it "very hard" to engineer an economic soft landing after its cycle of aggressive interest rate hikes, according to former Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan.

entries.title: Greta Thunberg on Abu Dhabi's oil chief leading COP28 climate summit: 'Completely ridiculous'
entries.description: The UAE, one of the world's top oil producers, will host the U.N.-led climate summit from Nov. 30 to Dec. 12, 2023.

entries.title: Orange bitcoin Mercedes owner at Davos hits back at critics, says not his car's fault people lost money
entries.description: The orange bitcoin car in Davos belongs to Michael Chobanian, the founder of Ukrainian cryptocurrency exchange Kuna.

entries.title: Jamie Dimon says rates will rise above 5% because there is still 'a lot of underlying inflation'
entries.description: Jamie Dimon believes that interest rates could go higher than what the Federal Reserve currently projects as inflation remains stubbornly high.

entries.title: The UK is fiscally unstable, says North Sea oil CEO
entries.description: The U.K. is fiscally unstable and its government is indulging in "short-termism" by slapping oil majors with windfall taxes, according to Amjad Bseisu, CEO of EnQuest.

entries.title: Greta Thunberg says Davos elite are prioritizing greed and short-term profits over people and the planet
entries.description: Thunberg said it was "absurd" that the world seems to be listening to Davos delegates rather than those on the frontlines of the climate emergency.

entries.title: Ad mogul sees Meta rebounding 'extremely strongly,' Amazon ad revenue hitting $100 billion
entries.description: Advertising titan Martin Sorrell believes Meta will rebound "extremely strongly this year" and sees a promising outlook for U.S. tech giants, despite a bruising 2022 and mass layoffs.

entries.title: Davos crypto crowd distance themselves from FTX and Sam Bankman-Fried: “It's fraud"
entries.description: Executives at Davos said the FTX collapse was not a crypto problem but alleged "fraud" by Sam Bankman-Fried.

entries.title: 'Discriminatory' measures in U.S. Inflation Reduction Act still need addressing, top EU minister says
entries.description: Valdis Dombrovskis said the EU and U.S. should be "building transatlantic value chains" for the green transition, "not breaking them apart."

entries.title: Top pharma CEO says Covid likely to become endemic, urges investment in pandemic preparedness
entries.description: Novartis CEO Vas Narasimhan made clear that world leaders must learn from the coronavirus crisis to be in a better place for future pandemics.

entries.title: Snow forces Britain's Manchester Airport to shut runways
entries.description: The U.K.’s Manchester Airport said it has temporarily closed both runways following a period of “heavy snow fall."

entries.title: European Central Bank member says will not stop at one single 50 basis point hike, 'that's for sure'
entries.description: The European Central Bank will not stop with one single 50 basis point hike at its next rate-setting meetings, one board member told CNBC Thursday.

entries.title: China's recovery may mean the Fed will have to hike rates longer
entries.description: China's speedier economic recovery could mean bad news for the U.S. Federal Reserve.

entries.title: China tightens media control with tiny stakes in two Alibaba units
entries.description: State-backed entities have taken tiny stakes in parts of two Alibaba subsidiaries that oversee a video platform and web browser.

entries.title: Trump mistook rape accuser E. Jean Carroll for ex-wife Marla Maples in deposition about photo
entries.description: Donald Trump has repeatedly said E. Jean Carroll, the writer accusing him of rape, is "not my type."

entries.title: Russian embassy tweets map that shows Crimea as part of Ukraine
entries.description: A Twitter account operated by the Russian Embassy in Sweden posted a map identifying Crimea as part of Ukraine.

entries.title: Treasury Secretary Yellen and China's Liu He talk U.S. tech policy at their first in-person meeting
entries.description: Chinese Vice Premier Liu He discussed U.S. tech policy toward China in a meeting with U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, the Ministry of Commerce said.

entries.title: Amazon discontinues charity donation program amid cost cuts
entries.description: Amazon is axing the program as CEO Andy Jassy undergoes a sweeping review of the company's costs.

entries.title: Investors are holding near-record levels of cash and may be poised to snap up stocks
entries.description: Investor cash holdings are near record highs, and that could be good news for stocks since there is a wall of money ready to come right back into the market.
